title: VULTERMINATOR: Bringing Back Template-Based Automated Repair for Fixing Java Vulnerabilities
data:
QC Bui, E Iannone, R Scandariato - 2025
Mainstream techniques for Automated Vulnerability Repair (AVR) lean heavily on 
Large Language Models (LLMs) and treat the vulnerability repair as a code 
translation task. Yet, their effectiveness is limited due to the complex nature of 
vulnerability fixes and, possibly, the lack of training datasets in the Java 
programming language. On the other hand, templatebased Automated Program 
Repair (APR) remains a popular way to fix general bugs. However, only a few
Cites: relifix: Automated Repair of Software Regressions

title: Fuzzing the Solidity Compiler Solc
data:
H Igaki, T Tsuchiya- Software Fault Prevention, Verification, and Validation, 2026
Fuzz testing (fuzzing) is an established technique for identi-fying software 
vulnerabilities by automatically generating a large volume of test inputs to uncover 
bugs. However, traditional compiler fuzzers are often designed for a specific 
language, making them difficult to adapt to others. To address this challenge, fuzzers 
that use Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate inputs for a wide variety of 
languages have emerged. This research aims to evaluate the effectiveness of
Cites: Fuzzing: Challenges and Reflections
